history.content:
(Context: Took CS294-112/131/158/159/190 as undergrad)

Although I've only taken special topics and not the more rigorous EECS upperdivs you're describing, many of my peers have. Worth noting that enrolling in these courses as an undergrad is very difficult. For example, to enroll in 227C this semester as an undergrad I think you had to complete a pset in the first couple days of school. And for example EE229A without significant (s i g n i f i c a n t) background knowledge will just lead to you scoring <33% on exams. All the undergrads in one of my grad classes this semester are spending 40-60 hours a week on homework that the grad students can finish in one sitting. It's not fun trying to compete with PhD students.

That's not to say that they aren't worthwhile. But as undergrads often a great deal of our pressure to learn in classes comes from the intrinsic tie between GPA in a course and learning. Not so in grad courses; from the 5ish grad courses I've taken as an undergrad, everyone gets an A. That can make it easy to slack off and I know many undergrads in courses who didn't take away much because the material was too hard and it was too easy to get an A.

If you enter with the right mentality, i.e. "I want to take away x y z concepts from this course because it will help me for a b c future ventures" and have the necessary prerequisite knowledge, you can learn an incredible amount by interacting closely with professors/grad students in very advanced material.

================

I'd like to add that you should consider auditing these courses.

(Context: Took CS294-112/131/158/159/190 as undergrad)

Although I've only taken special topics and not the more rigorous EECS upperdivs you're describing, many of my peers have. Worth noting that enrolling in these courses as an undergrad is very difficult. For example, to enroll in 227C this semester as an undergrad I think you had to complete a pset in the first couple days of school. And for example EE229A without significant (s i g n i f i c a n t) background knowledge will just lead to you scoring <33% on exams. All the undergrads in one of my grad classes this semester are spending 40-60 hours a week on homework that the grad students can finish in one sitting. It's not fun trying to compete with PhD students.

That's not to say that they aren't worthwhile. But as undergrads often a great deal of our pressure to learn in classes comes from the intrinsic tie between GPA in a course and learning. Not so in grad courses; from the 5ish grad courses I've taken as an undergrad, everyone gets an A. That can make it easy to slack off and I know many undergrads in courses who didn't take away much because the material was too hard and it was too easy to get an A.

If you enter with the right mentality, i.e. "I want to take away x y z concepts from this course because it will help me for a b c future ventures" and have the necessary prerequisite knowledge, you can learn an incredible amount by interacting closely with professors/grad students in very advanced material.

children.subject: It depends on how much interest or self-discipline you have. If you're auditing, you don't have to worry about 40-60 hr/week on homework unless you specifically want to do that work. On the other hand, it may be beneficial to take the class formally to force yourself to do it if you think that's better. I suggest auditing because either way, it's probably better to have a better idea of the course contents and gauge your interest first, then if you really want to, you can take it for credit the next semester to do all the work. It's probably better to have a clear idea of what you're getting yourself into if it's significantly higher workload than UG classes.

I don't know if you've taken grad classes before — but they are usually offered on a yearly basis so doing what you said is pretty unfeasible, not to mention you wouldn't get credit for those classes when applying to grad school

I have taken grad classes, yes. It depends on the reason you're taking them. If you're just interested in the material, or you're going to use it in industry rather than grad school, taking it for credit won't matter. Of course, grad school is a different story. It's still possible with classes offered once a year to plan to take them in a certain semester, then audit it a year in advance to make sure you really want to stick with the plan, get a preview of the content, etc.

@ student answer: how would auditing be a good idea? If anything, it seems like it would take even more away from Ashwinee's answer, as you would have even less sense of responsibility for material than you would in the class.

history.content: According to @4475, Prof Sahai recommends EE223, EE229A, EE227B or 227C as foundational courses to take while an undergrad pursuing AI/ML (graduate school). If you've taken any of these, could you comment on how you found the classes and if you think they were helpful in practice? And if not, which ones did you find more helpful? Thanks!
history.subject: Grad courses as undergrad for ML
